questions.text: A patient exposed to radiation presents with severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea within a few days. Based on these symptoms, what is the expected radiation dose that has likely caused this Gastrointestinal Syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Time Post-Exposure

Symptoms/Outcomes

Prodromal Phase

0–2 days

Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, fever, headache, early skin erythema (suggesting significant exposure >2 Gy)

Latent Phase

2–20 days

Temporary symptom improvement; abnormal lab results (lymphopenia, granulocytopenia) despite feeling well

Manifest Illness Phase

21–60 days

Symptoms vary by syndrome:

  • Hematopoietic syndrome (1-8 Gy, death in months):
  • Gastrointestinal syndrome (>5 Gy, death in 2 weeks)
  • Neurovascular syndrome (>20 Gy, death within 48 hours)

Final Phase

Recovery or Death

The outcome depends on the absorbed dose, dose rate, and exposure heterogeneity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and altered bowel habits. The physician suspects abdominal pathology and considers various imaging studies, weighing concerns about radiation exposure. Which imaging modality would expose the patient to the highest level of radiation?
questions.correct_answer: A. CT scan of the abdomen
questions.explanation:
Hazard Level

Modality

Investigation

Effective Dose (mSv)

DANGER

PET/CT/Radionuclide Studies

CT Abdomen

10

CT Thorax

8

PET

5

Bone Scan

4

CT Head

2 - 3.5

WARNING

Diagnostic procedures– multiple views

Barium Enema

7

Barium Meal follow-through

3

Barium Meal

2.6

Barium Swallow

1.5

Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU)

1.2

SAFE

Spot radiographs: Only 1 or 2 X-ray exposures to the patient

X-ray Lumbar Spine

1 - 1.5

X-ray Abdomen

0.7 - 1.2

Hip Joint

0.4

Skull

0.06

CXR (PA View)

0.02

Limb & Joint (Except Hip)

<0.01

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has recently started working in the radiology department and is concerned about radiation exposure. She seeks advice from the occupational health department. According to AERB guidelines, what is the maximum dose limit for occupational workers exposed to whole-body radiation in a year?
questions.explanation:
Part of the body

Occupational Exposure

Public Exposure

Whole body


 

20 mSv per year (averaged over 5 years) (Option B)

30 mSV in a year (maximum) (Option C)

1mSv per year

Lens of the eyes

150 mSv per year

15 mSv per year (Option D)

Skin and Extremities (hand and feet)

500 mSv in a year

50 mSv per year (Option A)

Pregnant radiation workers (once pregnancy is declared)

1 mSv (for the embryo/fetus)

2 mSv (for the pregnant women)

-

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who recently joined the radiology department was instructed to wear the device shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this device is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Assess the amount of radiation exposure

options.label: C
options.text: Should be sent for dose monitoring every 3 months

options.label: D
options.text: It is worn over the lead apron

questions.correct_answer: D. It is worn over the lead apron
questions.explanation:
TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge

Purpose

It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits.

Location

Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation)

Duration

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure. (Option C)

Composition

Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals: (Option B)

  • Calcium sulfate dysprosium
  • Lithium fluoride
  • Lithium borate
  • Berrylium oxide
Principle

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of breast cancer is scheduled for a follow-up PET scan. During the consultation, she expresses concern about the long-term effects of radiation exposure. Which of the following statements regarding the stochastic effects of radiation exposure is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The severity of the effects is dose-dependent

options.label: B
options.text: It can also result in radiation-induced cataracts

options.label: C
options.text: No threshold dose is required for the occurrence

questions.correct_answer: C. No threshold dose is required for the occurrence
questions.explanation:
Deterministic Effects

Stochastic Effects

Threshold dose

Required

Not required (occur by chance, at any dose) (Option C)

Severity

Dose-dependent (Option A)

Dose-independent
Dose increased

Severity increases

The probability of occurrence increases

Examples 
  • Radiation-induced cataract (Option B)
  • Skin erythema (most common side effect)
  • Radiation-induced cancer (most common is Leukemia)
  • Congenital malformations
  • Mutations

questions.text: In the context of the ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) principle, which of the following strategies is not aligned with minimising radiation exposure for healthcare workers during interventional procedures?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the distance between the operator and the radiation source.

options.label: B
options.text: Continuous fluoroscopy instead of Pulsed fluoroscopy

options.label: C
options.text: Implementing lead shielding and personal protective equipment (PPE).

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing the duration of time the patient is exposed to radiation.

questions.correct_answer: B. Continuous fluoroscopy instead of Pulsed fluoroscopy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. The attending physician is considering an abdominal X-ray. What does the "10-day rule" advise regarding X-ray exposure for women of childbearing age?

options.label: A
options.text: A gap of at least 10 days between two successive X-rays.

options.label: B
options.text: Avoid non-urgent X-rays within 10 days post-menstruation

options.label: C
options.text: Perform X-rays during the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle.

options.label: D
options.text: X-rays should be avoided 10 days before menstruation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform X-rays during the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for a CT scan to evaluate abdominal pain. The radiologist aims to ensure adequate visualization of the bowel without creating significant contrast between the bowel contents and surrounding tissues. Which of the following is a neutral contrast agent appropriate for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Type of Contrast Media

Description

Examples

Positive contrast media

Appear white on X-ray images due to greater attenuation of X-rays than surrounding tissues.
  • Barium (Option A),
  • Iodinated solutions (Option B)

Negative contrast media

Appear black due to less attenuation of X-rays than surrounding tissues.
  • Air (Option C)
  • Carbon dioxide

Neutral contrast media

Do not significantly alter X-ray attenuation, providing balanced contrast without adding brightness or darkness to the images.
  • Water
  • Mannitol (draws water into bowel loop)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is scheduled for an ERCP using the contrast mentioned below. Which type of contrast agent is it?
questions.explanation:
Iodine Particle Ratio
  • Ionic = 2 particles
  • Non-ionic = 1 particle
  • Monomer = 3 iodine
  • Dimer = 6 iodine

Ionic Monomer

Ionic Dimer

Non-ionic Monomer

Non-ionic Dimer

3:2

(High osmolality)

3:1

(Low osmolality)

3:1

6:1

Iodine Contrast

Routes of administration

Intravenous and Intra-arterial


 

Indications

Commonly used for contrast in CECT (3D X-ray), Interventional Radiology, and X-rays like as in

  • Intravenous pyelogram
  • Micturating cystourethrogram
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • Retrograde pyelography
  • ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Adverse Reactions

Physiological Reactions

Allergic Reactions

Post-contrast induced nephropathy
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Flushing
  • Headaches
  • Vasovagal reaction
  • Arrhythmias
  • Seizures
 

-

Mild reactions:

  • Hives (Urticaria)
  • Erythema (Redness of skin)
 

Moderate to severe reactions:

  • Wheezing
  • Anaphylactoid reactions (Non-IgE mediated)
  • Also known as Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI).
  • It is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Risk factors:
    • Patients with pre-existing kidney disease.
    • Pre-contrast eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m² indicates higher risk.

Management:

Observation for mild reactions

Management:

  • Mild reactions: Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine)
  • Severe reactions: Requires epinephrine and advanced airway management as needed.

Management:

Intravenous hydration (e.g., normal saline)

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The gastroenterologist is considering performing a barium study to assess her condition. Which of the following conditions would contraindicate using a barium study in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Conditions

Barium Swallow
  • To evaluate normal swallowing function.
  • Suspected oesophagal disorders (e.g., strictures, tumours)
  • Achalasia cardia
  • Zenkers diverticulum
  • Hiatus hernia

Barium Meal
  • To evaluate normal gastric emptying
  • Evaluation of gastric and duodenal conditions (e.g., ulcers, carcinoma, pyloric stenosis)

Barium Meal Follow-Through
  • Assessment of small bowel disorders
  • Malabsorption syndrome (Option A)
  • Ileocecal TB (Option C)

Barium Enema
  • Assessment of lower gastrointestinal tract (e.g. Colonic carcinoma) (Option B)

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman is being assessed for suspected appendicitis. An abdominal ultrasound shows inflammation but in limited detail. What is the best contrast agent to enhance USG?
questions.explanation:
Contrast agents for USG

Examples
  • Sonovue (sulfur hexafluoride)
  • Lumason (sulfur hexafluoride)
  • Definity (perflutren)
  • Sonozoid (perflubutane)

Preferred route

Intravenous

Eliminated by

Lungs (hence safe in Renal conditions)

Indications
  • Liver lesions
  • Micturating cystosonography
  • Renal lesions
  • Obstruction in Crohn's disease
  • Evaluation of Aortic aneurysm repair

Adverse Effects

It is the safest contrast media and rarely causes mild anaphylactoid reactions.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with multiple comorbidities is being evaluated for contrast-enhanced imaging. The healthcare team is assessing risk factors for contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). Which of the following is NOT considered a risk factor for CIN?
